Name: NetResults
Description:
The Synestructics company sold the building toy of the same name, which was a set of hollow rods of various lengths and connectors with various numbers of prongs, which together could be combined to build three-dimensional frameworks.

NetResults is a game which uses Synestructic pieces - one type of connector and one size of rod (in three colors).  Starting with a simple triangle, players take turns adding pieces to a common structure, attempting to complete polygons of any shape.  Points are awarded for the polygons based on the number of edges, with extra points awarded for completing polygons that use pieces from other players.

The game can be played by 2-3 players as individuals and 4 or 6 players in teams of two.

Name: Arnhem and Operation Market-Garden
Description:
This game was published in the May 1971 issue (Volume 3, Number 5) of Spartan International.

As indicated by the title, it is a wargame covering the fighting for Arnhem from September 17-25, 1944. It uses a fairly simple system, but does cover the salient points of the operation, including parachute drops, supply (including parachuted supplies), bridge blowing, etc.

In addition to the rules, the magazine includes an 11"x17" black and white map, an Order of Appearance sheet, 83 blue counters (German units and blown bridge markers), 44 beige counters (Allied units, air attack markers, and dropped supply markers), plus 1 more counter in each color which may or may belong to this game (the picture on each looks something like a mine).  The counters are on paper and must be mounted and cut out

Name: Denmark Straits
Description:
This game was published in the May 1971 issue (Volume 3, Number 5) of Spartan International.

It is a tactical naval game of the 1941 battle between the Bismarck and Prinz Eugen on one side and the Hood, Prince of Wales, Suffolk, and Norfolk on the other.  It is really a set of miniatures rules, with counters provided to be used instead of ship miniatures.  Six counters are included (one for each ship), sized for 1:1200 scale.

Name: Pythagoras
Description:
Ancient Greeks invent the board games (petties) and the most famous was "Pessoi" in many eras and with many differences.

Pythagoras of Samos is often described as the first pure mathematician. He is an extremely important figure in the development of mathematics yet we know relatively little about his mathematical achievements. Unlike many later Greek mathematicians, where at least we have some of the books which they wrote, we have nothing of Pythagoras's writings. The society which he led, half religious and half scientific, followed a code of secrecy which certainly means that today Pythagoras is a mysterious figure.

Pythagoras is the recreation of the Pythagorian "Pessoi".
This is a real ancient boardgame from ancient Hellas.

There is one board. 
There are 2-6 players. 
Each player has pawns. 
Pawns must have the signs of ancient Greek letters. 
Also there are three dice with ancient Greek shapes on them.
The player with the highest die roll plays first. 
All pawns must enter the board make a word.

The board game Pythagoras has the following items:
1. A Colorful Board.
2. Pawns/letters different in color and shape for each of the players.
3. One to Three dice  with different shapes on each one.
4. Many other items.

Name: Macedonia
Description:
Macedonia is an ancient region in Greece and also a board game of the "Pessoi".

The theme here is Greek Macedonia, one of the most beautiful regions of Greece, and an area which will grow in importance as the commercial and cultural center of the Balkans in the years to come.

This is an 2-6 player board game styled on ancient Macedonia with boards (petties) and ancient Greek letters from the Macedonian era.  Each player has ancient letters from ancient Macedonia Greece. Also there are three dice with the ancient Macedonian shapes.  Highest roll starts the game.

Macedonia has the following items:

1. Some Colorful Boards (Grids).
2. Ancient Hellenic Macedonian letters connected with numbers for each player (Aristotelian method).
3. Three dice with different shapes.
4. Other materials.
5. A leaflet with some information for this game along with photos from the ancient Macedonian region.

Name: Byzantium
Description:
Byzantium is the name given to both the state and the culture of the Hellenic Empire in the middle ages. Both the state and the inhabitants always called themselves Hellenes/Roman, as did most of their neighbors. Western Europeans, who had their own Roman Empire. The eastern Europeans called them Orientals or Greeks (Hellenes). Byzantion was the ancient name of the capital city and Byzantines gives the name of the Empire's capital city, as Constantinople (City of Constantinos the Emperor).

Byzantium is an ancient city in Greece and also a board game of Byzantium's "Pessoi".
This is an ancient board game from the ancient city of Byzantium with boards depicting the Byzantine era. Byzantium also called the Constantinople. Played with Byzantine Greek era letters for 2-6 players.
Also there are three dice  with the ancient shapes of Byzantium.
Highest roll starts the game.

Byzantium has the following items:
1. Some Colorful Boards (Grids).
2. Byzantium letters connected with numbers for each player.
3. Three dice with shapes.
4. Other materials.
5. A leaflet with some information for this game along with photos from the Byzantine era.

Name: Cosmic Runar Dice
Description:
Cosmic Runar (Runic) Dice

In ancient Europe there was a very popular dice game with the name Cosmic Runar (Runic) Dice. At first at the Orpheus period was only three cosmic dice. At the Homeric period there were four dice. At last there were totally twelve dice, for the 12 Gods. The Europeans create the runar (runic) scripts, so the Cosmic Runar Dice created.

The game comes with 12 cosmic runar dice  and the explanation for predicting your future according to the ancient Greek and European philosophers.
Also given is an explanation of how to use this game as a Rune Casting and fortune telling according to the scripts.

Cosmic Runar Dice has the following items:
1. A colorful grid.
2. 12 dice with runar (runic) scripts and letter.
3. A small book.
4. Many other items and a research book about runar script.

The full game which will be issued in the next version will have 25 cosmic dice  and much more information about the ancient philosophy of fortune telling.

This board game have been proposed to The UK Parliament for Olympic games in London 2012.

Name: Napoléon à Austerlitz
Description:
Apparently, the first wargame made in France. Published by the designer (Jean-Pierre Défieux) in 1977.

Very simple French wargame about the famous battle. It uses the simple attacker/defender odds table with elimination, retreat or "exchange". No command system, no special rules, a good game to introduce novices to concept of ZOC, combat odds, movement points...Large color map, basic NATO counters blue for French, green for Russians and white for Austrians.

Name: Shatranj
Description:
Shatranj has its origins in Chaturanga and is the predecessor to modern European Chess.  The two games resemble each other, but Shatranj is different enough that they can be considered two distinct games, even though it is Shatranj that Europeans first called "chess".

The main differences between shatranj and modern chess are that the earlier game had a vizier instead of a queen, and an elephant instead of a bishop, and these pieces had much more limited movement than their modern counterparts.  The pawn also lacked the double-step introductory move it has today, and furthermore, there was no castling.

While all this sounds very limiting, it can make a refreshing change from modern chess.  Modern openings must be left behind, and the pace of the game is a little slower, the limited movement of the pieces allowing defenses to be set up before the opponent approaches to destroy them.

Shatranj Kamil was an early and largely unsuccessful attempt to expand the game of Shatranj.

Name: Quads
Description:
The game is something like the better-known game "Battleship." In this game the players mark three squares (of four places) that the other playing is trying to find by guessing. The boards are plastic coated on particle board and marked with a grease pencil.

It was also released as a pad of sheets to be used with a regular pencil (or possibly two pads in a box), which were more professionally produced.

Name: Moto-Cross
Description: This game is quite unique with its theme as it is about motor-cross, a discipline that game publishers typically overlook. The goal is to reach the finish first and to score the maximum number of points. Each player either controls 1 or 2 motor-cross bikes. Each team has a budget and the races consists of 2 matches, the winner is the player who has scored the highest number of points over the 2 matches. Apart from dice, the game also consists of cards and a 34 x 47 cm. board. Vintage game from the '80s.

Name: Traffic
Description:
Traffic is a game about traveling in Switzerland.  The board shows a route of 45 spaces. 8 of them are petrol stations, which can be extended to service stations. The background of the board shows a detailed road map of Switzerland.

Each player travels across the route with a car, that can be chosen from 22 car cards. Some cars have cheaper upkeep costs than others, but they will reduce the income received when they land on the profitable bank spaces on the board.  But money can also be earned through petrol/service stations, obtained by correctly answering the question cards as well as by chance cards and the possession of special star chips.

These star chips are the main objective of the game, because the first player having 70000 francs in money plus 7 star chips, wins the game.

Traffic comes with some unusual components. First, there is a plastic bar with 23 holes. 
Rolling a glass marble in that bar replaces the roll of a die. Second, a 1.5 x 3 inch model car serves as challenge trophy. The winner gets this car until a next game is played. And third, 2x36 (traffic) question cards for children and adults are somewhat like a game in the game.

Name: A-divino
Description: A Mexican trivia game based on Catholic religion. Questions are divided in two groups: Practice and Culture; Practice questions refer to activities and behavior related to the Catholic Church, while Culture questions refer to historical and general knowledge questions that are somewhat related to Catholic religion.

Name: Multiplication Bingo
Description: Multiplication Bingo is an educational children's version of Bingo, designed to teach children multiplication, while retaining the flavor of Bingo.

Name: Le Wallon
Description: Players take on the role of Wally, the "mascot" Wallonia.  Players roll and move around a map of Wallonia from city to city visiting specific sites before returning to the starting locality to finish play.  Le Wallon is a children’s game meant to teach children about Wallonia, it's cities and it’s History.

Name: NOVENOPS!
Description:
(From publisher's website)

NOVENOP  is an acronym created from the words NOun, VErb, NOun, and Phrase and is a board game for children of ages 6 and up. NOVENOPS! has 60 cards that help develop the player's ability to understand the basic elements of grammar. Gameplay is designed to continuously reinforce the sentence structure concepts...while word familiarity improves reading and writing skills. Not only is NOVENOPS! a great learning experience-it's a hilarious game!

Name: UNO: Vacation
Description:
WHAT MAKES THIS DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: Check Two Card.

When this Check Two Card played by a player, he/she can:
- immediately play another card of the same suit color, OR
- play either Wild or Wild Draw 4 Card, the wild color called must match the color of the Check Two Card played.

However, this Check Two Card cannot be played:
- on its own (without a card of the same suit color), OR
- as the last card in your hand.
If the Check Two Card is the last card in a player hand, he/she must take another card from the draw pile. If the card just drawn matches the suit color of the Check Two Card, he/she may directly play the Check Two Card, say UNO, and play the matching suit color card to complete the game.

Name: Action Front! Watchtower
Description:
ACTION FRONT! Watchtower is the first in a projected series of  DTP microgames covering tactical combat in WWII.  The game's expandable system is reminiscent of the venerable Panzerblitz/Panzer Leader games, with a feeling of the Five-Star series thrown in.  Each game is played on 4 x 8 inch  semi-geomorphic maps, with a fast, furious sequence of play that minimizes bookkeeping and maximizes the action.  Players may play the included scenarios or create their own using the provided rules.

Watchtower comes with 20 US and 20 Japanese units, allowing players to recreate the epic struggle of the 1st US Marine Division on Guadalcanal in September and October of 1942.  USMC Raiders and Paramarines square off against Chi-Ha tanks and leg mortars.  Special rules are included for Henderson Field and banzai attacks.

In a small series with the Action Front! Hakko Ichiu.

Name: The Berenstain Bears Spooky Old Tree Game
Description: Take one of 4 bears and guide them through the spooky old tree.  Help get them out by using their flashlight, stick, rope and key.  First bear out wins.

Name: The Berenstain Bears Missing Dinosaur Bone Game
Description: Race through the rooms of the museum, finding all the missing objects.  If you are the first to find a dinosaur bone and return it to its proper place, you win!

Name: Le Combat de l'Aigle
Description:
Le Combat de l’Aigle (The Eagle's fight) is a tactical game system meant to simulate Napoleonic battles at the battalion scale. Large size battles are playable in one day. The game mechanism is close to miniatures, but the armies are included in the box as are several scenarios on the beginning of the 1809 campaign. Other volumes will follow.

Several rules are very innovative; a focus on unit cohesion (visualized by file closers set behind the unit), the chain of command, a cavalry combat using waves of squadrons close to reality. Other elements, (e.g. the brigade move) can accelerate the game. The combat system is based on drawing cards and comparing them (a simpler system based on a single die roll is also included).

Le Combat de l’Aigle can be played three different ways :

* As a tactical system to simulate real or imaginary battles..
    * As a miniature game system (Kip Trexel is the author of the campaign rules for Empire III). Basing and the use of miniatures, with single miniatures as file closers, are easy to adapt to any scale. Designed at first to be played with 6mm miniatures and doubling all distances included here, it can be converted to any scale with great ease..
    * As a tactical extension of the Vol de lâ€™Aigle campaign system, to solve every important battle. The players can decide to switch to a more tactical system when a large battle occurs.

The game includes 5 scenarios on the opening moves of the 1809 campaign.
Content (under ziplock):

* 1 rule book (32 pages).
    * 18 hard paper counter sheets including the French and Austrian armies at the beginning of the 1809 campaign in Bavaria.
    * 4 sheets of colorful player aid.

The players must provide numerical markers from 1 to 6 (we use 5mm dice).

Name: Die Siedler von Catan: Die große Karawane
Description:
Nomads established themselves in the oasis. The nomads desperately need wool and grain and offer commodities of the desert in exchange for them. Since the Cataners always have a few sheep and grain sheaves left over, the nomads send caravans out, in order to trade for the desired raw materials.
Through the course of the game, three caravan routes are formed with the caravan arrows. All settlements and cities on the caravan route count for one more victory point.  Any road running alongside the caravan's route counts double for the trade route.

Published as a free give-away by Kosmos in 2006.

Belongs to the Catan Series.

Name: 54x12
Description: The original title of this cycling game is about a gear that can be selected on a bike. This French game appeared at the end of the '80s. The game contains 4 double sided big boards representing a Tour de France étappe on each one. It's played with 2 dice, 40 tactics cards, 32 mountain cards, 26 sprint cards and 30 rouleur cards. Every player gets a team of 3 plastic cyclists. In the beginning every player gets a number of tactical cards. Movement is decided by the dice and influenced by the cards. In the mountains the number rolled by the dice is divided by two. Cyclists can also encounter a flat tire (caused by rolling two 1's with the dice), if this happens to the team leader, he can be helped by a teammate if necessary. Winner is the player who scores best in the overall classification. There is also a mountain prize for the player who has the best climber in his team.

Name: Les 45 Tours de France
Description: This game, releases either late '50s or early '60s, is in a very original format. The game has a 45rpm record (album size) with the instructions on it (side A contains a flat stage, side B a mountain stage), the gameboard is the backside of the record sleeve. The board has a drawing of France on it, with a track on the outside. Movement of the pawns is decided by dice rolling.

Name: 6 in Einem
Description: This German vintage cycling game dates back to the period between 1910 and 1920! It has two boxes, on with an oval indoor cycling track on it, the smaller box contains 12 metal cyclist. Players can either form a team of several cyclists or play just with one cyclist. Movement is decided by rolling 2 wooden hand made dice. There are six kind of disciplines that can be raced on the track : Sechstagerennen (6 day cycling), Fliegerennen (flying start), Auscheidungsfahren, Puntkefahren (points race), Dauerrennen (durability) & Mannschaftsrennen (teamrace).

Name: Internationales 6 Tage Rennen
Description:
This cycling game appeared somewhere in the 1970's in East Germany. The game has very original mechanics as the movement of the plastic cyclists on the oval indoor track on the gameboard is not done by cards or by dice but by a speedometer, a device that looks a bit like a spinner. That only makes this game a collectors item.

Not to be confused with 6-Tage Rennen.

Name: Le Jeu des 7 Tours
Description: Le Jeu des 7 Tours is a cycling game containing a large board measuring 69x49cms., 14 pawns (unfortunately no plastic cyclists, just classic pawns here), two dice and 70 cards with  questions about cycling. In the game it is possible to enter 7 different races. These are the Tours of France, Spain, USA, Japan, Benelux, Italy or Columbia. The tracks of these races are compiled out of a combination of flat stages, time trials and mountain stages. Movement is decided by rolling 2 dice, when someone rolls a 7 he has to draw a card and answer a question about cycling. The winner is he who wins the overall classifying of all races.

Name: Bicycle Race: A Game for the Wheelmen
Description:
This beautifully crafted vintage cycling game in a wooden box was produced in the USA at the end of the 19th century and truly a collectors item. There are 6 pawns, each representing a player. What makes it original is that movement is not decided by dice but by a spinning device (also ranging from 1 movement space to maximum 6). Every space on the board track also has text upon it, either giving the player luck or bad luck. Winner is the one who crosses the finish line first.

The same board and spinner looks to have also been issued under the name The Game of Bicycle Race"".

Name: La Boucle des Fruits Rhône-Alpes
Description: Cycling game released in the early '90s by a company from Valence (France) named Samourai to promote fruit from the Rhône-Alpes region in France. Each player has a team of 3 cyclists. The 4 available teams are the Apricots (orange color), Pêches (pink), Pommes-Poires (green with yellow) and the Petits fruits (red colored cyclists). There also are a cyclist with a yellow and green jersey for the leader in the classification (yellow general, green points). The mechanics are rather simple (dice rolling).

Name: B.S.A. Cycle Race
Description: Small simple cycling game released by the Chad Valley Company released somewhere in the 1930's. Movement is decided by dice rolling, certain spaces have text in them that can cause bad luck. The game was released to promote the B.S.A. company who were well known for their motorbikes but they also had a range of bicycles in their catalog in those days.

Name: Le Tour Butagaz
Description: Butagaz (subtitled 'Le Tour de France du premier butane français) was released in France in 1934 to promote the use of gas. The gameboard measures 37x28cms (A3 format). Movement of the pawns is decided by a die. As a curiosity, the cyclist who rejoins a Butagaz truck on a square advances two squares. The gameboard has a Tour de France map on it with the two Butagaz factories (in Paillac and Rouen) also mentioned on it. Winner is the player who's pawn reaches Paris first.

Name: Bunte Trikots, Blitzende Räder
Description: This game had several releases. It was originally released by Spika, a game publisher from Karl-Marx-Stadt (now Chemnitz) in East Germany (DDR). Bunte Trikots is a cycling game with a 47x34cm. board with an indoor oval cycling track (with 100 spaces) on it. The original version from 1959 had a blue background, the 1964 version a grey background. In the '60s a Belgian version (also with a blue background) was released in both French and Dutch language. There are 6 plastic cyclists (one for each player) that move after rolling a die. There are different rules for in total 5 different disciplines that can be raced on the track. Vintage game for collectors and cycling lovers.

Name: Corse Ciclistiche
Description: This Italian cycling game has a modular board, meaning that you can compile your own track by combining road tiles. There are also traffic signs that can influence the game. The mechanics are dice controlled. There are 4 different levels in this game. As often in racing games the winner is the one who covers the distance first.

Name: Maillot Arc-en-Ciel
Description: This beautiful self made game by Anki Toner from Barcelona contains 42 cyclists (in 6 colors); 2 dice, a cyclist in rainbow colors, 25 chance cards, 10 small and 10 big chits. The components of the game are in a solid wooden box. The gameboard (51x51cm) has a track on it that looks quite original. Movement is decided by dice rolling and the chance cards.

Name: La Serpiente Multicolor
Description:
This hard to find Spanish cycling game has cut-up cardboards who figure as the cyclists, there also are cardboard-signs. The game has a board with a track divided in different sections. Players also can alter the outcome of the race by playing tactical cards.

Free download from http://www.cyclingboardgames.net

Name: M6 Turbo Cup
Description:
M6 Turbo cup is a strategic simulation of a car race. T win the game U also have to obtain the correct licenses and hire staff (mechanics). Obtaining a license is done by getting hidden objectives during the race.

Components of the game: 1 board, 1 bloc note, 4 race cars, 4 team managers, 4 mechanic teams, 20 int. race licenses, 20 car control cards, condition cards, luck cards, safety cards and money.

Name: Snarps
Description: Snarps are monsters who intend to scare people out of their house. As a player you control such a monster and try to get other players out of the house. This game was nominated for a Pion d'Or by the Jeux & Strategie magazine in 1991.

Name: Captain Video: An Exciting Space Game
Description: Based on a TV Show that ran from 1949-1957, this is a game of space exploration in which players move their four markers through the solar system.  Movement is controlled by a spinner that is part of a fold-out cockpit which helps deepen the Captain Video theme.

Name: Space Game
Description:
This is a space exploration game for kids.  Players race through space using one of five metal spaceship playing pieces collecting treasure on the planets and space stations located on the board.  Players have the option of selecting one of two numbers after spinning for their turn.

An Australian version was produced by John Sands (Sydney) under licence from Parker Brothers. The concept of the game is the same but considerable differences in graphics can be seen on the board, spinner and box. The US version shows the Americas visible from earth while the Australian version shows Australia and south-east Asia. The spaceship playing pieces are the same as the US game although the instructions suggest only 4 players instead of 5 in the US version. As players advance around the board they collect (or lose) gold nuggets which are simply small stones painted gold. This also seems to differ from the collecting pieces in the US version.

Name: Strandburg
Description:
'Strandburg' (sandcastle) was produced in Austria in 1979. It is part of the first wave of cooperative games that hit europe(an kids) in the late seventies and arguably among the most intense experiences, because it features real experiences most kids have.

The goal of the game is to finish a sandcastle before it is destroyed by the rising tide. As with most of these games directed at players around the age of 5, decisions do not change the outcome of the game too much, it comes down to the luck of the dice.
Depending on the colours you roll on the 2 dice, you either add waves, parts of the sandcastle or help other players out. The feeling of being 'in this together' is very present.

Distribution in the Benelux was done by Jumbo, the game appeared there under the same name.

Name: Borodino 1812
Description:
A new concept of the military history publications. A book of history, a model, and if you wish,  a wargame.

The works are visual books. Their task is to reach those familiar with military history and make that the non-familiar become interested, by means of this glaring and easy system of reproducing a battle. By mounting a model, in a simple manner, you will be able to simulate the historical movements of the units or ships, using a co-ordinate system. For that, you will count on  the assistance of the Historical Handbook and the Battle Guide. Included are also rules for play alternate "what if?"

The box includes:
-Historical notes of the battle
-84x60cm board
-Laminated figures
-Deploy charts
-2 dice
...

For more information, check: www.deltaediciones.com

Name: Primo Calculino
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Reiner Knizia, himself a mathematician, has developed a new game in the “Clevermacher” series that will engage even notorious mathphobes: Primo Calculino. The ‘hero’ in this lovingly-produced game is the seller Johann, who has lots of tasty things for sale. Ready for the big sales, Johann, represented in the game as a seven cm high wooden figure, has not only the appropriate shopping tiles but also shopping bags in different sizes. And unfortunately, not everything fits into them! Little math artists will have to figure out more than just adding one plus one to make sure that only those things that belong land in the bags. The rest just wouldn’t fit.

Primo Calculino doesn’t just add enjoyment, it also subtracts and multiplies it. And so, while playing, mathematical abilities as well as memory and concentration are built. The nice thing is that nobody outside of adults will notice.

Description of the game from Selecta Spielzeug:

A mathematical learning game with many variations.

You can put so many tasty things into your bag, but sometimes, they don´t all fit! This game will teach little mathematical wizards more than just adding up one and one.

Contents: 1 figure, 36 task cards, 40 food cards (2½ x 2½ in.), instructions

Name: TurfMaster Course Collection 2
Description:
The second collection of extra courses for TurfMaster. This expansion includes one additional board with two race courses: Frankfurt and Leipzig.

Expands:

    TurfMaster

Name: Jona und der große Fisch
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Jona und der grosse Fisch (Jonah and the Big Fish) is by Uli Geissler and is a game about the story of Jonah. Jonah was given the assignment to travel to Nineveh. There, he is to ensure that the people make up for their mistakes. A difficult assignment for Jonah, who'd love to try and avoid it. In the game, the goal is to bring Jonah to Nineveh with the help of big fish, to save him and to prevent him from fleeing to Tarsis so that God's will can be carried out. All game figures are made of wood.

Name: Crossroad
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Crossroad is a card game originally developed for those involved in emergency planning, but is now also being widely released in Japan. The game is supposed to teach what can happen to the Japanese in the event of a catastrophic earthquake as well as what to do in such an event.

The game is for 5 to 7 players, and the number of players should be uneven if possible. At the start of the game, each player has the same number of 10 episode cards in hand. He also has a Yes card and a No card.

One of the players begins and reads the text from one of this episode cards. Then, the players try to guess how the majority of the players would act in the situation described. They choose either their Yes or No card, laying it face-down on the table in front of themselves.

Each player that chose the majority answer gets a point. These are represented by blue Zabutons (traditional Japanese pillows). The pillows have a symbolic meaning for many Japanese. Traditionally, Japanese comedians sit on blue zabutons during their performance, and they are sometimes given to others whose opinions are given the utmost respect.

But here Crossroad doesn't end - because it is highly honored when a player is alone in his opinion and manages to defend his position well. Here, a golden zabuton is awarded...

Toshiko Kikkawa is an organizational psychologist and professor at Keio University in Tokyo Katsuya Yamori is a social psychologist and professor at Kyoto University Tsuyoshi Ajiro is a freelance game designer

Name: Waimiri
Description:
Description of game from Spielbox:

Waimiri is a game about the aluminum trade in Brazil and was nominated for the Germaning Learning Prize 2006. The game concept: In the Brazilian rainforest, bauxite was found in the ancestral home of the Waimiri-Atroari (called the Waimiri in the game) - bauxite being the main aluminum ore. An international conglomerate has obtained a license from the Brazilian government to mine the ore. In this game, the Brazilian government, the mining company and the Waimiri negotiate the particulars and determine the consequences. Through construction of roads, factories and power plants the Waimiri lose their homeland.

Waimiri is a communications game for 3 groups, each of 3-10 players 14 and up, and is especially well suited for high schoolers from grades 9 to 12 learning about industry and the environment.

Name: Sport ist Mord
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

This game will help you, by playing as much sports as possible, to get really fit. But careful! Sports are dangerous! Those who train too hard and too much will easily get hurt, possibly even die. This game will show you just how shockingly dangerous sports can be. Since it's so dangerous, the game doesn't demand any sporting activity from the players at all.

The game includes 110 cards, 60 dice and various doping pills.

Name: Metropolen
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Metropolen (Metropolises) is also by Jorg Miethe. Here, the goal is to place the location of various metropolises on a blank map. The closer your X comes to the correct location, the more points you get.

The game was invented during a car ride from Stuttgart to Leipzig. There was a lot of traffic and therefore lots of traffic jams mentioned on the news. The inventor pictured a map of Germany during these announcements and tried to arrange the towns mentioned. From this situation arose the first prototype "Highway Guessing". This very quickly turned into the playable "Metropolen".

The game can be used by school classes as a geography learning game (for example in two groups playing against each other) or as an educational game for traveling groups or other parties. The game was tested in a casual group and was a real conversation starter ("I know where that is, I had the most unbelievable experience there...").

Name: Gebrauchtwagen Händler
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Used Car Dealer - Trash or Treasure is a card game by Jorg Miethe. Buy the best used cars from the other players and create the best car collection of all. But each used car has its secrets. Perhaps there's a treasure chest in the trunk or possibly hidden accident damage. Unfortunately, you can't trust anyone in this game. In the next round, it's your chance to sell and you can then try and foist the cursed cars on someone else.

The game is based on the "Lemon Game" from business theory. The lemon game is often used to explain credit notes in the banking industry. There are two important things that a lemon game needs. One player has more information than the other and there is a greater supply than demand. The theory says that in such situations, if a player does everything right, he's making the wrong choice! BTW, the name of the game comes from 'Lemon' being slang for a car you'd rather not buy.

Name: Schäfchen zählen
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Sheepworld - Schafchen zahlen (Sheepworld - counting sheep) is a fast-paced card game in which concentration, reactions and a sharp eye are needed! Black, white and red sheep are playing happily on the cards, but how many exactly? Count the sheep and quickly grab the right number card! The game was invented by Arno Steinwender and Andrea Steinhauser.

Name: Rechen-Kapitän
Description:
Ship ahoy with numbers from 1-20.

Where does the banana box go? Is this the place? At the harbor, the sailors load valuable freight in their ships. Each ship is distinctively large and must be loaded in the best way possible. Which ships fill up first and can begin the adventure on the high seas? The counting captain offers numerous exercises for the playful training of addition and subtraction in the number range from 1-20. The captain supports number understanding and promotes logical thinking. The option of playing alone lets children play and learn independently.

—description from the publisher (Translated by W. Eric Martin)

Name: Wiener Sammelsurium
Description:
Description of the game from the Spielbox:

Wiener Sammelsurium is a humorous quiz game by Harald Havas and Ronald Hofstatter. Have you ever wanted to know how many kilograms of horse manure are dropped daily on the streets of Vienna, or how many pieces of mail are sent daily to the Alterlaa buildings, or how many children Maria Theresia had? Answers to these and many more everyday and historical questions about Vienna are offered by this board game. Lost of questions and answers to the interesting and strange, curious and macabre about Vienna were turned into a humorous board game by the authors.

Name: Resi und Rudi Ringel
Description:
Description of the game from the Spielbox:

Resi and Rudi Ringel, the two young caterpillars, were brought to life by Brigitte Pokornik. Resi and Rudi want to know which of them is faster! Ready, set, go: The race over stick and stone is on. On a player's turn, he rolls the die. The end of the caterpillar is always placed ahead of the head, so long as the color collar is ahead as well. Then, the caterpillar's head is moved to that color. If a player rolls a color that the head is already on, then he may put a barrier up in front of the other caterpillar. That player must now navigate past the barrier. As soon as a caterpillar touches the goal flag, the game is over.

Name: Palm Beach Island Resort
Description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Palm Beach Island Resort is described as a tactical game. By placing needed infrastructure onto the spaces of the Island, a tourist resort is created that will be visited by guests from around the world. The goal of the game is to build Bungalows and encourage the tourists to part with their money; that is, make a tidy profit. Each player acts as a travel agent trying to fill his bungalows up.

Name: Definition: Cronicas Marcianas
Description:
"Definition" is a commercial version of the traditional family game of "Dictionary". Here, the players start with their rockets in Earth and have to reach Mars by earning votes for their definitions of weird words and points for guessing what the true definition of those words is.

In each turn a referee player, who changes after the end of the turn, draws a card in which different eccentric words are specified. The rest of the players write down a definition for the word secretly on a piece of paper. Then, the referee reads aloud all definitions and players have to vote which one they think is true (they cannot vote their own definition). According to the number of votes received for their definition or if they where able to find the true definition, the players can move their rockets towards Mars. Also, the dice can determine if the players ought to write a funnier definition instead of trying to find the true one, or if instead of a word it's a famous star that they have to define, or if the definition is given to them instead of the word and they have to find this last one.
The first player in Mars wins the game.

Name: The Reel to Reel Picture Show James Bond 007 Movie Trivia Game
Description:
An expansion for the Reel to Reel Picture show game, this game could be played on its own with home rules.

The questions fall into four categories which are color coded

Yellow covers the Bond Basics, questions about Bond Girls, Villains and the props.  These questions are usually the easiest of the four categories.

Pink covers the films of the Connery and Lazenby era.

Blue covers the Moore, Dalton and Pierce Brosnan films.  At the time of this game being made, only Goldeneye had been made for Brosnan.

Silver covers Extras and other background characters, credits, the various music of the films and catchphrases and quotes.  This category can be either very easy or quite obscure.

Name: Tee Time Golf
Description:
A dice-and-chart simulation of golf.  From the publisher's we site:

Tee Time Golf is a shot-by-shot golf simulation that allows you to coach the sport's greatest historical golfers, as well as today's best, over 18 holes on the world's premier golf courses. Professionals and some amateurs are available for purchase and they are rated using the same criteria. Golfers from the U.S., European, and Japanese professional tours are represented.

Name: Ten Events Decathlon Board Game
Description: Ten Events is a simulation of the men's decathlon competition and allows you to coach the event's all-time greats in a tabletop simulation.  Each athlete is rated for each of the decathlon's 10 events plus likelihood of injury.  Dice and charts are used to generate results for each event.  The game includes dozens of athletes including famous Olympians, athletes from the pre-Olympic era, and famous athletes from other events.

Name: Final Lap Auto Racing Board Game
Description: Final Lap Auto Racing is a dice-and-chart simulation of auto racing.  The game is purchasable with sets of drivers from recent seasons or all-time greats from Formula 1, NASCAR, and Indy racing.  Ratings for numerous tracks are included with the game.  Drivers are rated for their ability to claim pole position, finish races, finish on the lead lap, win races, and race finish if not the winner.

Name: Heavy Gear Blitz! Rulebook
Description:
Heavy Gear Blitz! is the latest (2006) Heavy Gear miniatures game from Dream Pod 9. A much more streamlined version of the original tactical game but in a very new design.  Still holding true to the Silhouette game system old players should find the game very familiar and new players should find it fast and easy to learn.  Its eliminates the hex based maps and uses a to-scale terrain system familiar to most miniature games.

The rulebook contains an introduction to the world of Terra Nova, the revised and streamlined rules, basic field guides for the forces on Terra Nova, a random scenario generator, 28 data cards covering all the standard vehicles in the field guides, as well as an assortment of counters for tracking the battle status of your army.

Name: Action Fractions
Description: American game releases at Essen '95. The components of the game consists of wooden pieces with 6 corners. It's an educational game to learn about fractions.

Name: Affen Angeln
Description: Each player controls an ape, goal is to swing from limb to limb (movement is done over tiles).

Name: Susan
Description:
RulesAn abstract game played on a hexagonal board of 61 spaces.


    9 . . . . .
   8 . . . . . .
  7 . . . . . . .
 6 . . . . . . . .
5 . . . . . . . . .
 4 . . . . . . . . i
  3 . . . . . . . h
   2 . . . . . . g
    1 . . . . . f
       a b c d e


Reminiscent of Go, but the rules are essentially:

Gameplay alternates between the two players, who each have their own color. A player's turn consists of either


     placing an off-board stone of their color on an empty space on board, or
     sliding an on-board stone of their color onto an adjacent empty space.


You cannot pass. If each player performs three slides in a row (meaning six consecutive plies or game actions being slides in total) then the game ends immediately in a tie.

You win as soon as any of the opponent's stones is surrounded on all liberties. Surrounding this stone is valid by any combination of own stones, opponent's stones, and even the board edges. But if your move causes one of your stones to be surrounded, you lose (even if you simultaneously surround an enemy stone!


    9 . . . . .
   8 . . . . . .
  7 . . . . . . .
 6 . . . . . . . .
5 . . . O O X . . .
 4 . . O . O X . . i
  3 . . . X X . . h
   2 . . . . . . g
    1 . . . . . f
       a b c d e


The diagram shows a situation where setting the next stone onto d4 would result in an immediate win of player X since stone on e4 would completely be surrounded. It does not matter if the surrounding stones are stones of player X or player O.

Suppose it is player X's turn: In the diagram shown above setting stone X on d4 is a win for player X since stone O on e4 gets completely surrounded.

Suppose it is player O's turn: In the diagram shown above setting stone O on d4 is a win for player X, too, since stone O on e4 gets completely surrounded.

Suppose it is player O's turn: Setting a stone onto c3 will continue the game. Player X cannot win any longer by setting his stone onto d4 since then he would lose immediately since this newly set stone is completely surrounded then. He loses even if stone O on e4 gets surrounded simultaneously.


    9 . . . . .
   8 . . . . . .
  7 . . . . . . .
 6 . . . . . . . .
5 . . . O O X . . .
 4 . . O . O X . . i
  3 . . O X X . . h
   2 . . . . . . g
    1 . . . . . f
       a b c d e


Instead of placing a stone, you can instead slide one of your stones on your turn.


    9 . . . . .
   8 . . . . . .
  7 . . . . . . .
 6 . . . . . . . .
5 . . . . . . . . .
 4 . . . . . . . . i
  3 . X O . . . . h
   2 O X O . . . g
    1 . O . . . f
       a b c d e


Note that in the diagram above stone X on b2 is perfectly safe. Neither player can set onto a1 without losing the game, since the stone set onto a1 would be completely and directly surrounded. The result would be the active player's loss of the game.

				
				
					References
     Original rules text: http://www.stephen.com/sue/sue_man.txt
         Note that Stephen Linhart's page uses a different game notation
    
     About the game: http://www.stephen.com/sue/sueabout.html
     Java version of the game Susan: http://sourceforge.net/projects/susan/
         Note: the Lawa Susan does not seem to include the rule on draw situations on six consecutive set of stones
    
     Play by email server: http://gamerz.net/pbmserv/susan.html
     There is a computer version available for the Macintosh as well: http://www.stephen.com/sue/suemac.html

Name: Dungeon Twister: Purple Dragon
Description:
Purple Dragon is a mini-expansion for the Dungeon Twister series of games. The character comes in blue and orange colors.

For 2 AP's (plus a song) the Purple Dragon (stats: 2/6) can invoke an acid rain to destroy all portcullis in a room. The Dragon is worth 2 VP when destroyed.

The expansion was given out at the 2006 Essen fair.

Expands

    Dungeon Twister

Name: Dungeon Twister Collectors Box
Description:
With the purchase of the collector's box comes membership into the exclusive Dungeon Twister Club. The club offers additional information, puzzles, tournament invitations, specials, etc. Membership is free and limited to 1000 members.

The collector's box is limited to 1000 copies!

Name: Hungry Hound
Description: This is a battery operated kids game that has a motorized hound dog in the middle of the game which spins around, opening and closing it's mouth as players try to flip small bone-shaped chips from small spring-loaded paws into it's mouth.  It is very similar, if not identical, in game-play to "Mr. Mouth"

Name: Pop-Cheks
Description:
From the box: "Pop-Cheks is a new and exciting way of playing checkers, using the "Pop-o-matic""

A six-sided die inside of the pop-o-matic bubble tells which color gets to go next.  In this fashion, players may lose their turn or get multiple turns in a row.

Name: Maestro Leonardo: Codex Leonardi – II
Description: This expansion for Maestro Leonardo (Leonardo da Vinci) was distributed in Essen 2006 to the buyers of Maestro Leonardo and adds one more area to the city: the market. There the players have a chance to exchange hand cards with the cards that are already in the market. The exchanged cards remain in the market for future exchanges.

Name: Kings and Queens
Description:
A game of skill featuring the lineage of the Kings and Queens of the UK.

A game for 2 players where players maneuver their pieces on a grid attempting to get the value of their 6 pieces to equal 30.  Each King and Queen has a value ranging from 1 to 8 based on their recognized titles: Henry the 8th is 8 points, Edward the 2nd is 2 points and so on.

Each player moves pieces orthogonally or diagonally and has to move as far as they can before stopping.  The game ends when a player reaches 30 points.

Name: Fredericus: Sigillum Magnum
Description:
This is an expansion given to the buyers of Fredericus in Essen 2006.
Now you can, instead of betting on a keep, bet on a capture of any other player. If that player captures two creatures you win 2 goal cards.

Name: Palatinus: Insula Tiberina
Description:
This is one expansion given to the buyers of Palatinus in Essen 2006.
It replaces one random territory tile from the base game.

Name: Musketier: Im Auftrag der Königin
Description: Paris in 1625. The players take over the role of the musketeers Athos, Porthos, Aramis and D'Artagnan trying to travel from Paris to Calais. During the travel the musketeers are attacked by the troops of cardinal Richelieu. Each round one of the musketeers must sacrifice in order to fulfill their quest. The one surviving is D'Artagnan the winner.

Name: Bolide Tracks #1: Roma (Italy) and O Copo (Brazil)
Description:
Two new tracks for the Bolide race game.

    Roma (Italy) - Ancient Fashions
    O Copo (Brazil) - Champions' Curves


Expands:

    Bolide

Name: Caillou Gigantik Game
Description:
A children's game for ages 3+ based on the animated television show Caillou.  The object of the game is to pick up all your toys and return them to your toy box.  The first player to pick up all their toys and return to their room is the winner.

The game is distinguished by the Gigantik play mat board which is layed out on a giant plastic mat to be played on the floor rather than a regular style board.

Name: Square Routes
Description:
Classic abstract strategy game. Make the colors work for you. Out-think your opponent. A good game of strategy and counter-strategy.

Redeveloped into


     Kamisado (adds continued play with promotion and varied board reset)

Name: Das Eisenbahnspiel
Description: Travel around Germany by train in this hard to find game. "Board" is a rolled up inside a triangular tube. Players try to visit as many German cities as possible using specific rules and some dice rolling.

Name: Hit
Description: Japanese mob-themed card game. Players try to make the most successful "hits" without getting caught.

Name: Nanawa: Verdun in the Chaco War, July 1933
Description:
(from the Firefight Games website)

Nawana was a turning point battle. It was here, a Bolivian Army led by German General Kundt, armed with new weapons (tanks, flame-throwers, fighter-bombers) assaulted the Paraguayan defenses not from Paraguay's capitol. Kundt had been led to believe the defenses were weak, that the tanks would break through and that once Nanawa fell, the road would be open to Paraguay’s capital. This was in fact true, however, that was the only thing which was true. The Paraguayan forces had been issued special antitank ammo and built well defended trenches with mines. Their lines were not weak and numerically almost as strong as the Bolivian! The Paraguayans had proved themselves many times during this war as a very dangerous foe even when outnumbered. After three days of fighting and a combined body count of over 4000 men with little real gain, the Bolivians halted.

Components:
1 11x17 inch map
280 counters, 
Player aids

Scale:
Company-level
1 hex=250 yards
1 turn=8 hours

Name: Roundabout Five
Description:
From the media kit:
In Roundabout Five, players compete as individuals on teams that randomly change their composition and size on every turn (Dynamic Teams). On regular game cards, teams encounter trivia, odd comparisons (Which happened first? The United States attacks Libya or the Culture Club releases Do You Really Want to Hurt Me) , riddles, jokes, math and grammar problems. Second Option cards introduce elements such as debate (Would Daffy or Donald Duck last longer on the cartoon version of Survivor?), charades and personal trivia (Was I born before or after Woodstock?) to the game, creating a whole new level of fun. R5 can be played by 3 or more adult players for a total point objective, select number of turns or within any given time constraint.

Home Page: http://www.roundaboutfive.com

Name: Hiwataka
Description:
For the first time, Little Wolf and his friends are allowed to get the necessary food for their families. They have beautifully made tomahawks and earthenware jugs, leather clothes and feather headdresses on board their canoes to exchange for pumpkins, herbs, maize, and fish. It's an exciting adventure because the river is treacherous and it is not always immediately possible to steer to the right market stand.

A quality wooden game from Beleduc.

Ages 4 and up.

Name: Bengali
Description: The elephant keepers are very busy because the cheeky elephants are always running away and hiding in the jungle. So, they have decided now to build a separate enclosure for each elephant to put an end to the tiresome searching.

Name: Daisy Racy
Description: The lambs frolic and romp on the meadow. The mother sheep have eaten almost everything in the meadow so they must make their way together with their lamb over to another grazing spot. To ensure that none of them gets lost, the little lambs must always stay close to their mothers. To encourage them not to forget in their exuberance, they are given daisies as rewards if they follow their mothers instead of running on ahead.

Name: Quakies
Description:
Beautiful water lilies bloom on the pond and not only the ducks come to marvel at them. The cheeky frogs also love the water lilies and each frog tries to get hold of as many as possible before the large dragonfly comes and snatches the remaining blossoms.

Ages 4 and up.

Name: Pajonk
Description:
To board shows a spiral with spots for the stones. Objective is to get all of he own stones connected. You either move a stone or switch two stones in a line where you have the majority.

The gameboard is made up of leather and doubles as a pouch to hold all the pieces. There are two versions: The normal one and "Pajonk Extreme" with a bigger board

Name: Cinco de Mayo: The Battle of Puebla, 1862
Description:
CINCO DE MAYO is a game on the battle between a division of French troops in the army of Emperor Maximilian and those of the Republican forces of Mexico for control of the key city of Puebla, a battle that led to the Mexican national holiday honoring its date, May 5 (1862).

CINCO will use the same system as was used for both LINE OF FIRE and EAST-WEST, a firepower oriented version of the time-honored BSO system used in the MEN OF IRON system, with somewhat different focus. The battle itself uses some very interesting, colorful terrain, along with the usual units with the evocative names: 2nd Zouaves, the Fijo de Morelio Battalion, Chasseurs d’Affrique, the Oaxaca Lancers, etc. Special rules cover cavalry lancer charges, square formation, a rather early use of trenches, and artillery ammo.

Most of the rules and mechanics will be quite familiar to anyone who has played BSO games, but all with a nice period flavor.

Playing time for CINCO has averaged 2-3 hours, sometimes less, and the rules are only 9 pages.

CAVEAT: This battle will also be featured in an upcoming GMT module (for their GRINGO game) that will be published late 2007, early 2008. It uses a totally different more complex system, though

Each game of CINCO DE MAYO includes Rules, one sheet of Mike Lemick’s great-looking cut-and-paste counters, and a colorful Pascal da Silva 22”x17” game map and game cover.

Name: Galathea ekspeditionen
Description:
Follow in the footsteps of the Danish Galathea 3 expedition. The biggest Danish scientific expedition in 50 years. It plays two ways; get fastest through the ships route, or fill the log book first, both ways you have to have the right answers.

Contains: 1500 questions in the categories: Expeditions,nature & technology, history & culture and geography.
25 picture cards, 1 board, 6 game pieces, and a dice.

Name: Detectives
Description:
London 1905. Alan Baddy, sinister and evil character, greatest exponent of organized crime, tenaciously chased by Scotland Yard for his terrible misdeeds, has gone back to his old ways. Which detective will first locate the building where Alan Baddy committed the crime, finding the incriminating proof?
 In this deductive game, first who plays Alan Baddy is randomly determined, the rest will play the astute detectives. The one playing Alan Baddy´s role will have to prepare the other elements of the game: decide in which building (11 pubs, restaurants and hotels altogether) the crime was committed, and assign the incriminatory proof (fingerprint, footprint and ring) of his crime to one of the buildings. All buildings will contain proof, but only one will contain the relevant ones with the required features.
 During the game the detectives will have to search the different buildings on the board gathering clues in every one of them and making notes of them in their "Detective Notes" sheets, followed by Alan Baddy who'll do everything in his/her power to frustrate their quest.
 The winner is that player who discovers in which building the crime was committed, contributing the proof which corroborates his/her hypothesis.

Name: Black Hole: Space Alert Game
Description:
The game is based on the Disney movie "The Black Hole".  Leave the explorer craft to explore the massive ghost ship Cygnus, but Cygnus is doomed! By drawing playing cards, players must plot the fastest escape route, avoiding androids and Maximilian!

Players draw and discard action cards in order to move around the board.  If no card matches the next space's icon, they discard a card but do not move.  The first player to make it through the Cygnus to the Space Probe wins!

Name: Rocket Race to Saturn
Description: Using a spinner, players take turns moving their plastic spaceships through the solar system in a somewhat random order that eventually ends at Saturn.  Players encounter obstacles on the way that may slow them down or help their progress.  The first to reach Saturn wins.

Name: Tipsi!
Description: This is a four player game where the object to pick up one of four silver clay marbles at a time with a wooden spade.  Players must then balance the marble as they attempt to deposit them it on top of a sort of column.  The first player to successfully place four marbles is the winner.

Name: Baumhaus Club
Description:
What fun!  A "house warming party" in a tree house! But first all of the children have to bring their toys, food, and tools up to the tree house. It's not so easy especially if you don't know where you've left your belongings! A lively game for memory training.

The game looks terrific, too, with great components and a good 3-D tree house.

Name: Duckys
Description: All sorts of things are happening on the water lily pond. Four pairs of ducks are now proud parents, and all of the ducklings have escaped from their nests and are now sitting on the island in the center of the pond. The parents face the difficult task of finding their baby ducklings so they can bring them back to their own nests.

Name: Bailen 1808
Description:
Included in the box:
-2 84 x 64 cm rigid boards
-1 42 x 64 cm rigid board
-48 figures of the units
-18 figures of the generals
-Historical book
-Battle Guide
-Campaign guide
-Rules for the wargame
-80 chits
-2 deploy tables
-52 plastic bases

The set contains all the information about the battle of Bailen between the French and Spanish troops that took place in the little town of Bailen in Spain, plus a wargame to recreate it.

For more information: www.deltaediciones.com

Name: Zing!
Description:
From the TLI Games website:

"Let the stories begin…..Zing! gives you a delicious set of words (with three difficulty levels). With those and a few of your own, you develop a sentence. You’ll score points for every Zing! word you use. Players take turns adding to your sentence until you have a story!

Can’t write? You’ll be surprised… Zing! brings you in and gets you creating, writing and laughing in a flash! Discover new ways of thinking.

And when the stories have been told (after a few twists and turns) the player with the most points wins!"

Name: The Take Away Game
Description:
You are a buyer for a Big Building in the States, for example, the Empire State Building or the Pentagon. It is your job to supply the building with beautiful and affordable lounge suites. The aim of the game is to collect Seats and Sofas lounge suites in six different colors for your building. However, to do this, you only have a limited amount of dollars at your disposal. The player who is the first to collect at least one lounge suite token in all six colors for his building is the winner of the game. 
It is a game specially developed for a giant seller of furniture: Seats and Sofas. 
Rules in Dutch and English. 
There is a version with rules and cards in English and French.

Name: Chicky Picky
Description:
What a hullabaloo in the chicken coop! The little chickens are very hungry and the mother hens are looking for earthworms to feed them. Which chicken gets full the fastest?

This game won the Deutscher Lernspiel-preis in 2004.

Name: Her Mit Dem Fisch
Description:
There is a lot going on in Adelie Land. Catch fish together with Mama and Papa Penguin and feed the little penguins. Be careful, as the little penguins can still help to catch the fish for dinner!

dupe of Hey, That's My Fish! ??

Name: Tirili
Description:
Making a nest, lining it with feathers, laying eggs, and taking care of the little birds is not as easy as it might seem. The bird parents are always therefore grateful for a bit of help. Who will be the first to have his three little birds in the nest?

Ages 4 and up.

Name: BrummSummsel
Description:
Leni and Frederick like walking over the brightly colored flower meadows in the summertime. There is a lot to discover there and they can admire the many different types of insects.

Most of all, the two of them like the fat cuddly bumblebees. They are a little bit clumsy as they fly around and make a particularly loud buzzing sound, but they are just as busy as bees when it comes to collecting the delicious nectar from the many blossoms.

Name: Castello del Drago
Description:
The castle dwellers are in a state of panic. Six dragons are prowling around the area, waiting for the opportunity to conquer the castle. Luckily, though, the valiant knights are on hand to help. By closing ranks and uniting forces, they battle to drive away the dragons.

A very fun game with a dexterity element to knock down the dragons by using a ramp like a cannon.

Castello del Drago is for ages 5 and up.
